Graphical abstract The state-of-the-art types of hybrid electrolytes for supercapacitors (SCs) are reviewed, and the effects of the different hybrid systems on the performance of SCs and the underlying mechanisms are also summarized. Supercapacitors (SCs) are emerging as efficient energy storage devices but still suffering from limited energy density compared with batteries. Electrolytes have been regarded as the key to determine the energy storage performance of SCs. However, none of the conventional electrolytes can fully meet the increasing requirements of SCs in terms of high ion conductivity, excellent stability, wide voltage window and operating temperature range, as well as environmentally friend concerns. To this end, hybrid electrolytes have sprung up in recent years, which are believed to be the candidate to solve these shortcomings. Herein, the state-of-the-art types of hybrid electrolytes for SCs, including the combination of aqueous and organic, aqueous and gel polymer, ionic liquids (ILs) and organic, and ILs and gel polymer hybrid electrolytes, are reviewed. The effects of different hybrid systems on the performance of SCs and the underlying mechanisms are among the focal points of the review, and prospects and possible directions are discussed as well to provide further insight into the future development of this field. Keywords Supercapacitors Hybrid electrolytes Energy density Power density Wide voltage window 1 Introduction With the increasing attention to energy and environmental issues, supercapacitors (SCs) are highly valued as new type of energy storage devices by the governments of all countries [1–7]. SCs are also called electrochemical capacitors, whose energy density and power density performances are between batteries and ordinary capacitors. Compared with traditional capacitors and batteries, SCs have a larger capacity than traditional capacitors, and faster charge and discharge rate than batteries. SCs have been widely used in the low load situations such as electronic products of mobile phones, video recorders and notebook computers, and matched batteries in such high-power load situations as electric vehicle power systems and tank climbing systems [8–10]. They can also be used as capacity compensation and recovery in starting and braking motor vehicles. In addition, SCs can also efficiently store photovoltaic power and wind power in the power generation mode to achieve grid-connected power generation [11–15]. SCs are mainly constructed with electrode materials, current collectors, separators and electrolytes. As an important part of SCs, electrolytes have a large impact on the electrochemical performance of SCs. However, in the past decade, researchers are conventionally more inclined to modify the electrode materials to achieve improved performance of SC devices [16–25]. So far, there are few reviews and comments specifically on electrolytes of SCs. Until 2015, Zhong et al. [26] systematically reported a review of electrolytes, including the category of electrolytes, the principles and methods of designing and optimizing electrolytes, and the challenges in producing high-performance electrolytes, and proposed several possible research directions to improve the energy density of SCs without sacrificing existing superiorities such as high power density and long-term cycling life. The requirements of electrolytes for SCs can be summarized as follow: high ion conductivity is the key to minimize the internal resistance of SCs, especially during large current discharge; the electrochemical stability and chemical stability of the electrolyte must be high enough to sustain long working life; the operating temperature range should be wide to meet the varying temperature of the working environment; the size of ions in the electrolyte should match the pore size of the electrode material (for electrochemical double-layer capacitors); and the electrolyte should be environmentally friendly [26]. Moreover, according to the theoretical prediction of the energy storage in SCs determined by the formula of E = 1/2 CV 2 [27–37] (E is energy density, C is the capacitance, and V is the working voltage of the capacitor), the working voltage should be high to achieve high energy density. Each electrolyte has its own special characteristics and none of them can match all of the above requirements. For example, compared with aqueous electrolytes, organic electrolytes and ionic liquids (ILs) have wider electrochemical stability windows (>3.0 V), which remarkably enhance the energy density [38–40]. However, organic electrolytes have safety problem because of their flammable nature, and ILs have higher viscosity and lower conductivity compared with organic electrolytes, especially at low temperature. Moreover, ILs and organic electrolytes are sensitive to moisture, which demands sophisticated purification and ultra-dry manufacturing procedures. Recently, some researchers began to focus on the modification of electrolytes, and some new type of hybrid electrolytes have been reported, and greatly boosted electrochemical performances have been achieved. We therefore, review recent progresses and developments in the research of new type of hybrid electrolytes for SCs. The effects of the new type of hybrid electrolytes properties on the performance of SCs and the underlying reaction mechanism as well as their applications will be discussed in details. Focusing on improving the SCs energy density without sacrificing other existed advantages, several possible research directions to address the challenges will be summarized and proposed as well. It is worth noting that the results and conclusions drawn from the application of hybrid electrolytes to SCs are also applicable to lithium/sodium ion batteries, mental ion hybrid capacitors and so on. 2 Traditional electrolytes for electrochemical SCs Traditional electrolytes can be generally divided into aqueous, organic, IL and solid- or quasi-solid types (Fig. 1 ) [41–47]. As the first type used in SCs, aqueous electrolytes are featured with high ion conductivity, low internal resistance and small molecule diameter, which can easily permeate through micropores. Aqueous electrolytes are mainly used for pseudocapacitors and electric double-layer capacitors (EDLCs) that involve electrochemical reactions. The research of aqueous electrolytes is mainly focused on acidic, neutral and alkaline aqueous solution, and H2SO4 and KOH aqueous solutions are most commonly used. The volatility and narrow electrochemical potential window are the main drawbacks of aqueous electrolytes, which therefore set up the bottleneck for energy density. The working voltage of a SC is determined by the decomposition of an electrolyte on the electrode surface at high potential. The wider working voltage range an electrolyte of a SC has, the wider working voltage the SC will produce. The working voltage of a SC can be raised from 0.9 V to 2.7 V using organic electrolytes instead of aqueous electrolytes. At present, the common working voltage of commercial SCs with organic electrolytes is 2.7 V [48]. Because the energy density of a SC is directly proportional to the squared working voltage, a lot of research efforts are devoted to developing electrolytes with high conductivity, good chemical and thermal stability, and wider electrochemical windows. An organic electrolyte system is mainly composed of an organic solvent and a supporting electrolyte [44]. The main characteristics of an organic solvent include low volatility, good electrochemical stability and large dielectric constant. And the research goal of organic electrolytes is to achieve the optimal ratio of various organic solvents to match the supporting electrolyte and electrode materials. Water should be avoided as much as possible in organic electrolytes, which will reduce the capacitor performance and induce the aggravation of self-discharge [49]. In addition, the overcharge of the capacitor will produce toxic volatile substances, and at the same time, the power storage capacity will be significantly reduced or even lost [50]. In recent years, as a new type of green electrolyte, IL has been widely used in SCs, especially in the field of EDLCs [51–53], which is featured with wide electrochemical window, relatively high conductivity and ion mobility, wide liquid range, almost no volatilization and low toxicity. SCs working with ILs thus have the characteristics of good stability and durability, no corrosiveness of electrolyte and high working voltage. But the too high viscosity of IL leads to the disadvantage of this type of SCs. And the specific capacitance of IL-based SCs is still much lower than that of the aqueous electrolytes. The reason is that the IL electrolyte and activated carbon (AC) cannot be well infiltrated [54]. Because temperature has a relatively large effect on such parameters as conductivity and viscosity of the ILs, the performance of IL-based SCs is more sensitive to environmental temperatures. Nevertheless, ILs electrolytes are still one of the most active fields in the research of SCs. Solid electrolyte systems are featured with good reliability, no electrolyte leakage, high specific energy and high working voltage, which make it possible to develop miniaturized and ultra-thin SCs. However, due to the low conductivity of most polymer electrolytes at room temperature, poor contact between electrodes and electrolytes, and the relatively low solubility of electrolyte salts in the polymer, the practical application of solid electrolytes in SCs faces lots of challenges [46,47]. Among several types of solid electrolyte systems, all solid-state hydrogel electrolyte SCs are environmentally friendly and exhibit wide potential applications. Because of water contained in the electrolytes, the conductivity of hydrogel polymers is generally higher than other solid-state electrolytes. In addition, solid-state hydrogel electrolytes of alkaline type are generally better than acidic type [55]. In summary, each type of electrolyte has its own advantages and disadvantages, and it is difficult for a single type of electrolyte to meet the increasing requirements of SCs. New types of hybrid electrolytes have emerged as promising candidates for SC applications in recent years. 3 New types of hybrid electrolytes for electrochemical SCs In view of the above considerations, the new types of hybrid electrolytes are mainly based on the mixing of traditional electrolytes of different types, such as aqueous and organic, aqueous and gel polymer (Tables 1 and 2 ). The hybrid combination of different types of electrolytes leads to novel reaction mechanisms, applications and future prosperity. 3.1 General composition, mechanism and SC performance of new types of hybrid electrolytes New types of hybrid electrolytes reported in recent years can be roughly divided into four categories, namely aqueous and organic, aqueous and gel polymer, ILs and organic, and ILs and gel polymer combinations (Fig. 2 ). By hybrid mixing of the electrolytes, the properties of voltage window, ion conductivity, applicable temperature range, etc. are improved, which thereby enhance the energy density and rate performance of the constructed SCs. 3.1.1 Aqueous and organic hybrid electrolytes In recent years, aqueous electrolytes have been widely explored for electrochemical energy storage [26,56–58]. Compared with ILs and organic electrolytes, aqueous electrolytes are inherently safe and easy to handle. However, pure water decomposes above 1.23 V and the narrow electrochemical stability window of water has limited their practical application [59,60]. Since Wang et al. [61] developed the “water in salt” (WIS) aqueous electrolyte that can be prepared via dissolving lithium bis (trifluoromethane sulfonyl) imide (LiTFSI) in water at ultrahigh concentrations (>20 m). The types of WIS electrolytes have been widely used in aqueous lithium ion batteries and sodium ion batteries [61–69]. Xu et al. [70] investigated SCs made of rose petal-derived porous carbons with different concentration LiTFSI WIS electrolytes, a working voltage 2.4 V was obtained, and an energy density of 44 W h kg−1 was achieved at 564 W kg−1 and 60 °C using 20 m LiTFSI electrolyte. Dou et al. [71] reported that the introduction of acetonitrile (ACN) into a WIS electrolyte (AWIS) resulted in a wide electrochemical stability window, non-flammability, high conductivity and a low freezing temperature. Such new types of aqueous/organic hybrid electrolyte enable SCs to have a high operation voltage, a high power density and a wide applicable temperature range. The capacitance using an AWIS is 2.4 times larger than the original WIS electrolyte at 10 A g−1. A SC with this kind of AWIS electrolyte can cycle over 14,000 periods at a high operation voltage of 2.2 V. It’s worth mentioning that there is still a large gap in the operational voltage comparing to commercial organic SCs (2.7 V). But the expensive imide-based salt will also hinder the application of this kind of SCs. Dou et al. [72] reported a super-concentrated aqueous/organic hybrid electrolyte, namely cheap sodium perchlorate salt mixed with water/AN solvents (the molar ratio of salt/water/AN are 1:1.5:2.4), which showed a high conductivity of 41.2 mS cm−1 and high-level safety. The SC assembled with commercial activated carbon as the electrode and using such a hybrid electrolyte demonstrated excellent rate capability and an operational voltage of 2.5 V. Xiao et al. [73] explored the influences of the types and the amounts of the added organic solvents on physicochemical properties of the hybrid electrolytes between ACN, dimethyl carbonate (DMC), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and propylene carbonate (PC). AS a result, the introduction of ACN is capable of improving the ion diffusion of WIS electrolytes. It has been found that ACN is the best to enhance the ion diffusion while maintaining high-level safety and wide electrochemical stability windows. An optimal hybrid electrolyte (LiTFSI/H2O/(ACN)3.5) is employed to construct carbon-based symmetric SCs, which can fully work at 2.4 V with excellent rate capability and cycling stability over 40,000 cycles. These aqueous and organic hybrid electrolytes open up new horizons in developing high-performance energy storage devices including SCs, metal-ion hybrid capacitors and metal-ion batteries [74]. 3.1.1.1 The structural analysis Super-concentrated WIS electrolytes have been successfully applied to high-voltage aqueous lithium-ion batteries and sodium-ion batteries. However, due to strong electrostatic cation–anion attraction, the conductivity of the WIS electrolytes is low and the viscosity is high, which limit the rate performance of aqueous batteries, as well as SCs. Dou et al. [71] developed an ‘‘acetonitrile/water in salt’’ (AWIS) electrolyte by adding acetonitrile to salts, which could effectively improve the conductivity and reduce viscosity. As shown in Fig. 3 , Raman spectroscopy measurements and density-functional-theory-based molecular dynamics (DFT-MD) simulations reveal that the presence of acetonitrile molecules leads to a spatial isolation effect which weakens electrostatic cation–anion attractions while the strong coordination between water molecules and lithium ions is preserved. As a result, AWIS electrolytes can significantly enhance the specific capacitance, rate capability, and low temperature robustness of SCs, without sacrificing the operation voltage and cycling stability [71]. 3.1.1.2 The effect of different concentration Different concentrations have distinct effects especially on flammability. Although acetonitrile is a highly flammable solvent, it can be non-flammable for certain changed concentrations of the electrolytes. As shown in Fig. 4 , for the concentration of 3 M AWIS, the electrolyte is flammable due to the larger portion of acetonitrile. When the concentration increases to 5 M, the electrolyte is non-flammable. It was found that the optimal concentration of 5 M leaded to the best combination of conductivity, viscosity and safety of the AWIS electrolyte [71]. Xu et al. [70] investigated the electrochemical performance of carbon-based SCs with LITFSI WIS electrolytes of different concentrations at temperatures ranging from −20 to 100 °C, and they found that lower concentrations are suitable for lower ambient temperatures, and higher concentrations are better for higher temperatures. 3.1.2 Aqueous and gel polymer hybrid electrolytes The WIS electrolytes can mix not only with organic solvent, but also with gel polymer [75,76,78–80]. Liu et al. [75] mixed a 21 M LiTFSI WIS solution with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), and the LiTFSI-PVA gel electrolyte maintained the wide operation window of the WIS electrolytes and exhibited superior water-retention capability under extremely dry atmospheres and at high temperatures. Consequently, the quasi-solid-state SC constructed with such a gel electrolyte were able to operate at 1.8 V with long cycling lifetime from room temperature up to 120 °C, which is the best temperature record among the previously reported aqueous gel-based SCs. Qin et al. [76] reported a novel class of WIS gel electrolyte of SiO2-LiTFSI applying to VN//MnO2 planar asymmetric micro-supercapacitors (AMSCs) with exfoliated graphene as the conductive agent and current collector. It is worth noting that the as-fabricated MSCs exhibits remarkably enhanced energy density of 21.6 mWh cm−3, which is superior to most MnO2 based MSCs. This work paves the way towards further construction of microscale electrochemical energy storage devices into miniaturization. In addition to MSCs, quasi-solid-state fiber-shaped aqueous supercapacitors (FSASs) with superior cycle stability and mechanical flexibility have been considered as one of the most promising candidates for high performance energy storage devices in wearable consumer electronics [77]. However, the relatively low energy density is still a challenge for current FSASs systems. Liu et al. [78] reported a novel symmetric FSAS using surface-wrinkled and N-doped reduced graphene oxide fiber (NRGF) as the electrode, whose performance matched with highly-concentrated LiCl/Polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) gel polymer electrolyte (GPE, 8.96 M), exhibiting a large specific capacitance of 151 mF cm−2 and a broadened voltage operation window of 0–2.2 V which is the widest voltage operation window among symmetric FSASs. An energy density of 25.6 μWh cm−2 at 0.5 mA cm−2 was obtained, which is much higher than its counterparts reported previously, and it can work at temperatures from −20 to 70 °C [78], indicating the possible applicability of FSAS in wide temperature conditions. It is noteworthy that the introduction of neutral LiCl/PVA GPE ensures the safety of FASA especially in the case of wearable electronics which involve the direct contact with human skin. Aqueous and gel polymer hybrid electrolytes are mainly employed in quasi-solid-state SCs and micro SCs, which can effectively improve the range of application temperature and voltage window and thereby enhance the energy density and rate capability of the SCs. Such method is also suitable for aqueous lithium ion batteries and zinc ion batteries that operate at high temperature. 3.1.2.1 The structural analysis Aqueous gel electrolytes get the most attention owing to their advantages of high ion migration rate, low-cost and ease of use in constructing quasi-solid-state and solid-state SCs. However, when used at high temperatures, severe dehydration will affect the ion migration ability of aqueous gel electrolytes, which thereby invalidates the SC devices [75]. As shown in Fig. 5 , DFT-MD simulations were performed to identify the effect of PVA added in the LiCl-PVA and LiTFSI-PVA gel. In the case of 1 M LiCl-PVA gel, most of the water molecules are in a free state. In the LiTFSI-PVA gel electrolyte, Li ions are coordinated with water molecules through oxygen atoms and unsaturated Li+ ions bond to TFSI- anions partially. Moreover, Li+ ions are bonded to the PVA chain through the oxygen atoms. All of these features are beneficial to the structural stability of the 21 M LiTFSI-PVA gel, which also increases the water-retention capability. The severe dehydration problem is thus solved, which demonstrates a new horizon in promoting high-temperature applications of SCs. 3.1.3 ILs and organic hybrid electrolytes On the premise of not sacrificing the power density, it is particularly important to improve the energy density of SCs in practical applications. According to the equation E = 1/2 CV 2, the energy density (E) is proportional to the electrode capacitance (C) and the square of the potential window (V) of the electrolyte. It’s well known that ILs have superior potential windows to aqueous and organic electrolytes, which have attracted extensive research interest. However, the high viscosity of ILs leads to the low mobility problem of ions, which has limited their applications at low temperatures. Commercially available non-aqueous SCs mainly operate at −40 °C or higher temperatures, and they usually show poor performance below room temperature [81,82]. It is therefore necessary to improve the low-temperature tolerance of the SCs for real-life applications. Researchers have made a lot of efforts to address these drawbacks. Mixing with various solvents is especially effective to improve the stability of electrolyte at low temperatures. There is a plenty of organic solvents that can be mixed with ILs to obtain tailored properties for task-specific functionalities. Carbonate- and lactone-based liquids, such as propylene carbonate (PC), adiponitrile, acetonitrile or γ-butyrolactone (GBL), are considered as promising candidates for designing electrolytes with a wide range of working temperature because of their high boiling points and low melting points [38,83–87]. Tian et al. [88] proposed a binary electrolyte that combines GBL with 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate (EMIMBF4) for EDLCs, and dramatically improved ionic conductivity and temperature window were achieved. The assembled device with a mesoporous grapheme electrode exhibited a capacitance of 131 F g−1 and an energy density of 61 W h kg−1 at the temperature of −70 °C with an applied voltage of 3.7 V, which are the highest values reported so far. Lang et al. [89] investigated a series of electrolytes by dissolving EMIMBF4 or TEABF4 in an appropriate binary solvent system such as acetonitrile (AN), N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF), propylene carbonate (PC), using such organic co-solvents as methyl acetate (MA), n-pentane (NP), and ethanol (EA). The optimal combination of the EMIMBF4/acetonitrile/methyl acetate-based electrolyte enables the constructed SC with activated polyaniline-derived carbon as the active material to work at a high potential window of 3.5 V, which delivers a maximum energy density of 80 W h kg−1 and a power density of 26 kW kg−1 at a very low temperature of −50 °C. Lu et al. [90] also employed a binary solvent that combines the EMIBF4 with PC and 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) for EDLCs. The capacitor employing an AC electrode with such an electrolyte yields an energy density of 38.5 W h kg−1 at about 900 W kg−1 for a cut off voltage of 3 V. All the work has revealed that the mixing of ILs with organic solvent, binary organic solvents or even polynary systems can effectively broaden the temperature range especially at the low temperature side, and thereby widen the practical application of SCs. 3.1.3.1 The structural analysis As shown in Fig. 6 , NMR and ATR-IR characterizations were used to investigate the interaction of GBL with EMIMBF4 [88]. As revealed in Fig. 6(a and b), the presence of GBL and PC results in the red shift of active hydrogen in the rings of EMIMBF4. And the shift of the former peaks is much larger than the latter, which reveals the effectiveness of GBL in breaking up the ion pairs of EMIMBF4. Furthermore, Fig. 6(c) indicates that the adding of GBL can significantly affect the peak of βC-H-in-plane in the imidazole rings, while the added PC has no effect on the peak. These results demonstrate that GBL has a strong interaction with EMIM+ via the hydrogen bonds, leading to the good dispersion of ILs. As a result, the glass transition temperature (T g) is significantly reduced and the ionic conductivity is increased with the addition of GBL. It is worth mentioning that the lower value of T g indicates the more stable nature of the ILs-solvent solution. All these factors lead to the stable work performance of the device at a low temperature of −70 °C. 3.1.3.2 The effect of different concentration Tian et al. [88] investigated the electrolyte properties of the system of GBL and EMIMBF4 with a series of volume ratio E1G1 (EMIMBF4:GBL = 1:1), E1G2 (EMIMBF4:GBL = 1:2), E2G1 (EMIMBF4:GBL = 2:1) and E10G1 (EMIMBF4:GBL = 10:1). Among these, the volume ratio of EMIMBF4:GBL = 2:1 shows the best electrolyte properties. As presented in Fig. 7 (a), the ionic conductivity of E2G1 is 23.9 mS cm−1, approximately 1.6 fold that of pure EMIMBF4, revealing the dissociation of the ion pairs of EMIMBF4 by GBL. However, the ionic conductivity doesn’t increase linearly with the further addition of GBL, which indicated that no ion pairs of EMIMBF4 can be further dissociated in E1G2 and E2G1. Besides the conductivity, the viscosity can also be effectively influenced. The viscosities of E2G1, E1G1, E1G2 are 20.7, 12.2 and 10.1 mPa·s at 20 °C, respectively, all lower than that of pure EMIMBF4 (about 40–70 mPa·s as shown in Fig. 7(b)). It’s worth noting that the viscosity of E1G2 at −70 °C was 433 mPa·s, which is only one order lower than that of pure EMIMBF4 at the ambient condition. This property makes it possible for EDLCs to operate at low temperatures. The addition of PC also broke up ion pairs of EMIMBF4 (E1P1). However, E1P1 became unstable below −80 °C, and the solvation of PC in EMIMBF4 didn’t lead to expected improvements in either ionic conductivity or viscosity. 3.1.4 ILs and gel polymer hybrid electrolytes As a kind of molten salt at room temperature, ILs have many advantages such as non-volatile, no-flammable, and most importantly, high operating potential window (>3 V), but the problems of potential leakage and internal short-circuits have hindered their further applications in SCs. Many researchers are shifting their focus to IL-based gel electrolytes (ionogel electrolytes) [37,46,92–98]. Ionogel electrolytes can maintain the original features of ILs, such as wider operating potential ranges, high conductivity and non-flammability, and the bottleneck issues that ILs encounter can be effectively solved as well. Song et al. [92] reported a well-designed ionogel electrolyte with a wide potential window of 3.5 V, with which the assembled symmetric device with a N, O co-doped honeycomb porous carbon electrode delivered an energy density of 94.1 W h kg−1, exceeding the same type of reported SCs. In addition, such a new type of hybrid electrolytes can also be employed in fiber SCs (FSCs), which are promising energy storage devices to complement or even replace microbatteries in miniaturized portable and wearable electronics. However, compared with rechargeable batteries, FSCs still have the serious problem of low volumetric energy density. Pan et al. [93] designed an all-solid-state asymmetric FSC (AFSC) that employed a gel-polymer incorporated with ILs as the electrolyte, MnO x @TiN nanowires@carbon nanotube fiber as the positive electrode and C@TiN NWs@CNT fiber as the negative electrode, and an ultrahigh stack volumetric energy density of 61.2 mW h cm−3 with a maximum operating voltage of 3.5 V was achieved, which is comparable to commercial planar lead-acid batteries (50–90 mW h cm−3). This device demonstrates new direction towards designing flexible AFSC for wearable and portable applications. There are many kinds of ILs and gel polymers that can be selected for this kind of electrolytes, and the combination of different types leads to distinct effects and performances. Pal et al. [94] investigated the effect of different ILs, including 1-butyl-2,3-dimethylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate, 1-butyl-3- methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate and EMIMBF4, with poly(vinylidene fluoride -hexafluoropropylene, PVDF-HFP) on the electrochemical performance of EDLCs. They found that the hybrid electrolyte formed with EMIMBF4 and PVDF exhibited the smallest cation size and the highest ionic conductivity. There are also some other efforts to combine redox-additives with IL and GPE based electrolytes, and improved SC capacitance can be achieved [99–107]. For example, Yadav et al. [108] developed a novel GPE that consists of redox additive hydroquinone (HQ), 1-ethyl-3-methyl-imidazolium hydrogen sulphate (EMIHSO4), poly (vinyl alcohol) and poly (vinylpyrrolidone) (PVA/PVP/EMIHSO4/HQ), and the synergistic effect of porous AC and IL-based redox active gel polymer electrolyte resulted in a superior performance to other carbon-based electrodes (multiwalled carbon nanotubes, graphene nanoplatelets) and H2SO4-based GPE. 3.1.4.1 The structural analysis As mentioned in the foregoing sections, it is a good choice to select IL to increase the voltage window so as to improve the energy output of SCs. But the instability of liquid electrolytes may cause safety problems of leakage and internal short-circuit. As a result, mixing ILs with 3D gel polymer matrix can be a first-rank choice. After mixing ILs with gel polymer, ILs can be well confined to the structure of the cross-linked network [92]. As shown in Fig. 8 , the prepared polymer gel is a transparent solid with high flexibility, which can be used as a solid substrate for ion transport. The SEM images reveal a porous network architecture with a rough pore size about 3–8 μm, which can facilitate fast transport of ions into the interior pore channels of the carbon-based electrodes. The structural advantages make the device easier to be shaped without causing the problem of potential leakage. 3.2 The reaction mechanisms and effects of different hybrid systems Each single electrolyte has the different reaction mechanism, which is highly dependent on the electrode materials. For example, SCs with aqueous electrolytes usually employ carbon materials and metal oxides as electrodes. The main energy storage mechanism of carbon-based aqueous SCs can be attributed to the reversible electrostatic accumulation of ions on the surface of porous carbon [109,110]. The charge storage of metal oxide-based aqueous SCs relies on the faradic redox reactions of metal oxides, which belongs to faradaic pseudocapacitance. Most of the organic electrolyte-based SCs are double-layer capacitors using porous carbon as electrode materials [111]. The mechanism of electric storage is to store charge through electrostatic accumulation. The organic electrolyte-based SCs are essentially electrostatic, and no chemical reaction occurs in the process of use, which enables the devices with high service life. Unlike aqueous and organic electrolytes, ILs can be used as electrolytes for SCs without solvents, and rely on their own dipoles to form electric double layers on the surface of charged electrodes [51–53]. There is no doubt that the reaction mechanisms of new types of hybrid system are related to the single electrolyte. Further understanding of the underlying reaction mechanisms of hybrid electrolytes may need the means of in-situ characterization, which is still lacking in exploring new types of hybrid electrolytes at present. The detailed information will be discussed in the end of perspectives. The new types of hybrid electrolytes discussed above are all obtained by mixing two or even more components. As shown in Table 1, each type of hybrid electrolytes has wider cell voltage than its single electrolyte such as aqueous (<2 V) and organic (~2.7 V) electrolytes, which enables the higher energy density. Besides, IL-based hybrid electrolytes show larger voltage windows than the other electrolytes. In addition, different types of hybrid electrolytes possess different applicable temperature ranges. The disadvantages of IL-based hybrid electrolytes are the high cost of imide-based salt and ILs, which may hinder the application of such kind of SCs. Therefore, the selection of appropriate hybrid electrolytes for cheaper and environmentally friendly SCs is crucial to the future research. The mixed systems are similar to composite materials, which can retain the advantageous properties of each component, and supplement the deficiency of a single electrolyte. For example, in the aqueous and organic system shown in Fig. 9 (a), WIS itself has a wide potential range, but it also has the intrinsic problems of low conductivity and high viscosity. The addition of an organic solvent can effectively improve the conductivity and reduce the viscosity of the system [73]. Compared with a single aqueous or organic electrolyte, the energy density and the rate performance of a combined system can be largely improved, and the assembled SCs can work at temperatures ranging from −30 to 50 °C [71], indication potential applications in lithium-ion batteries and lithium-ion hybrid capacitors. Moreover, WIS gel electrolytes have excellent water-retention and even water-absorption capability, which enables a quasi-solid-state SC to work at 120 °C in an extremely dry atmosphere, superior to SCs made of aqueous gel electrolytes [75]. In mixed organic systems with ILs, such as EMIMBF4-GBL electrolytes can effectively improve the ionic conductivity, which leads to a specific capacitance up to 131 F g−1 for SCs constructed with a mesoporous graphene electrode and an energy density of 61.3 W h kg−1 at the temperature of −70 °C and the voltage of 3.7 V [88]. The viscosity of ILs is higher at low temperatures, which greatly reduces the ion mobility. The hybrid method of mixing with other types of certain species can improve the conductivity at low temperatures [89–91]. Compared with aqueous and organic electrolytes, IL is a kind of molten salt at room temperature, which is non-flammable and non-volatile, and generally employed as a green electrolyte with a wide voltage range. However, there are leakage and internal short-circuit problems with ILs due to their intrinsic instability. The combination of ILs with ionogel electrolytes (IL-based gel electrolytes) are the solution to these problems. Plenty of ionogel electrolytes have been developed for applications in portable and wearable electronic devices [92–94]. There are many factors that can affect the electrochemical performances of SCs. As shown in the Fig. 10 , each electrolyte of a single component has its own drawbacks, and the hybrid electrolytes of multiple components can supplement one another to realize wide voltage window expansion, improved ionic conductivity, reduced viscosity, reduced ionic size, improved stability, and so on. When combined with electrode materials of high performance, the energy density of the constructed device can be further improved, which is more conducive to the practical development and application of energy storage devices. 3.3 The applications and developments of new types of hybrid electrolytes As shown in Tables 3–6 , most of the new types of hybrid electrolytes were employed in constructing EDLCs and solid-state SCs, which were usually accompanied with modified carbon-based or pseudocapacitive materials as the electrodes to further boost the energy density of SCs. They can also be applied to pseudocapacitors and hybrid SCs, which are promising energy storage devices for portable and wearable electronic applications. Moreover, the new hybrid electrolytes also have competitive applications in other fields such as metal ion batteries, metal ion hybrid capacitors and molecular electronic transducer sensors. The strategy of developing hybrid electrolytes provides us with a new development direction in designing electrolytes. The constructed SC devices based on the hybrid electrolytes all exhibit superior electrochemical performance to original single electrolyte in wider potential windows and temperatures ranges, higher energy density and power density performances and so on (Tables 3–6). At the same time, the energy density of the SC can be further improved by combining the electrode materials with high specific capacitance, so that it can be better applied in practice application. We have reason to believe that in the future development, new types of hybrid electrolytes will definitely receive more and more attention and play an important role in energy storage equipment. 4 Conclusions and perspectives As an indispensable component of SCs, electrolytes deserve intensive investigation, but the related studies have always been in a tepid state. (Seen in Fig. 11 ) More research efforts are focused on modifying the electrode materials, and there not many reports on electrolytes every year. It is in recent years that the proportion of electrolyte literature gets increased slightly, especially about the new types of hybrid electrolytes which have attracted our interest and led to the original intention of this review. The properties of the electrolyte, such as the electrochemical stable potential window, ionic conductivity, viscosity and thermal stability, etc., essentially determine the device performances of SCs, including the energy density, power density, charging rate, cycle and temperature. As mentioned in the foregoing sections, a single electrolyte has its specific drawback, and cannot perfectly fulfill all the performance requirements of SC devices. The philosophy of hybrid electrolytes provides a straight and efficient direction towards developing full-functionality electrolytes for SCs as well as other energy storage devices. Although there are many reports on new electrolytes, and some of them adopt Raman spectroscopy, DFT and some other characterization techniques to explore the mechanism of the new type of hybrid electrolyte for improving performance, while the research is still on the scratch. New types of hybrid electrolytes for SCs are urgent need to develop. It is true that the development of new hybrid electrolytes provide us with a new research direction in designing electrolytes. However, there are still many uncertain factors in their working mechanism. The enhancement mechanism of hybrid electrolytes to SCs is still in the exploratory stage. As an old saying in China that “Give a man a fish and he ends for a day”, if we can understand the enhancement mechanism of hybrid electrolytes in principle, we can fundamentally modify it, rather than blindly copy others. To understand the working mechanism of different types of hybrid electrolytes, the characterizing techniques and methods are very important. In addition to the conventional techniques such as Raman spectroscopy and the simulation methods such as DFT calculation, in-situ characterization techniques are very useful to study the internal mechanisms of the hybrid electrolyte systems. Some in-situ characterization techniques such as in-situ Raman, in-situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and in-situ X-ray diffraction (XRD) have been developed to study lithium ion batteries, electrocatalysis and other electrochemical materials [112–115], which can also be used to systematically explore the internal reaction mechanism of the new type of hybrid electrolytes in SCs. Taking in-situ XRD for example, put the electrode material of lithium ion batteries into an in-situ XRD cell, which connects with X-ray diffractometer and battery test instrument, the phase transitions and the structural changes within electrodes can be monitored real-time [115]. Besides the work performance of SCs such as the important factor of energy density, the cost and environmental impacts are also very important concerns in evaluating the practical application of an electrolyte. Fully understanding the internal reaction mechanisms of the hybrid electrolytes can enable us to develop high-performance energy storage devices with low-cost and environmentally friendly electrolytes. In the new hybrid electrolytes mixed with binary or multiple components, the synergistic effects of mixed components results in supplemented and improved electrolytes properties which therefore enhance the electrochemical performance of SCs, such as an expanded voltage window, increased ionic conductivity, reduced viscosity and ion size, and improved stability. Achieving high energy density without sacrificing power density is the very challenging goal for SC devices in contrast to rechargeable batteries. We believe that the new type of hybrid electrolytes will have their development prosperity in the future, and the combination of high-performance electrolytes with high specific capacitance electrode materials will jointly promote the practical application of SCs and definitely become an important research direction in the field of energy storage devices. Wuquan Ye received his M.S. degree in Chemistry from Ningbo University in 2019. Now, he is a Ph.D. student in Prof. Yong Hu’s group at Zhejiang Normal University. His research interests mainly focus on the synthesis of electrode materials for supercapacitors and Zn-air batteries. Haiyan Wang received her Ph.D. degree from Zhejiang University in 2018. From 2018 to 2019, she was a postdoctoral fellow at Zhejiang University and then she joined Zhejiang Normal University as a lecturer in 2019. Her interests are mainly focused on electrode materials for energy storage and conversion devices, including supercapacitors, Zn-air batteries and water splitting. Jiqiang Ning received his B. S. degree in 2000 and M. E. degree in 2003, both from the University of Science and Technology of China (USTC), and his Ph. D. degree in 2007 from the University of Hong Kong (HKU) where he then worked as a postdoctoral researcher in the lab of laser spectroscopy at the Physics Department. He is currently a professor at Suzhou Institute of Nano-tech and Nano-Bionics (SINANO), Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), and his current research is focused on optical spectroscopic studies on non-linear optical phenomena, electronic behaviors and defect states in semiconductors and their nanostructures. Yijun Zhong is a Full Professor at the College of Chemistry and Life Science, Zhejiang Normal University (ZJNU), China. He joined ZJNU in 1983 and is a visiting fellow at Institution of Catalysis, Zhejiang University for two years. He received his Ph.D. degree in Industrial Catalysis from Zhejiang University of Technology, China in 2008. His research interests include the design and application of inorganic nanostructures for industrial catalysis and energy conversion and storage. Yong Hu obtained his Ph.D. degree in inorganic chemistry from University of Science and Technology of China (USTC) in 2006. He then worked as a research fellow at Nanyang Technological University (NTU). Stating from 2008, he has been a full professor at the College of Chemistry and Life Science, Zhejiang Normal University (ZJNU), China. His current research interests are focused on the design and synthesis of nanomaterials for energy and environmental applications.

coredata.dc:description: Supercapacitors (SCs) are emerging as efficient energy storage devices but still suffering from limited energy density compared with batteries. Electrolytes have been regarded as the key to determine the energy storage performance of SCs. However, none of the conventional electrolytes can fully meet the increasing requirements of SCs in terms of high ion conductivity, excellent stability, wide voltage window and operating temperature range, as well as environmentally friend concerns. To this end, hybrid electrolytes have sprung up in recent years, which are believed to be the candidate to solve these shortcomings. Herein, the state-of-the-art types of hybrid electrolytes for SCs, including the combination of aqueous and organic, aqueous and gel polymer, ionic liquids (ILs) and organic, and ILs and gel polymer hybrid electrolytes, are reviewed. The effects of different hybrid systems on the performance of SCs and the underlying mechanisms are among the focal points of the review, and prospects and possible directions are discussed as well to provide further insight into the future development of this field.
